caption_original: COOL SCIENTIST ALERT! Here’s Benoit, one of our biologists studying the health of freshwater in Cape Breton, Nova Scotia, using *CABIN methodology. By sampling and studying invertebrates, he can tell a lot about how healthy the freshwater is. *CABIN is the Canadian Aquatic Biomonitoring Network, a network of groups working together to assess the health of freshwater ecosystems across Canada. In using CABIN methods, partners take observations using approved protocols and make scientific assessments using national standards.

caption_original: Here we are, four biologists (two in front, one way in the back, and yours truly behind the camera), installing a fence through a small tree-lined wetland at the Last Mountain Lake National Wildlife Area (NWA), Saskatchewan. We need fences like this one to keep our local “vegetation managers”() from wandering off the NWA and onto the roads and neighbouring properties. They munch away to keep our grasslands healthy! It took a lot of elbow grease to install this -km fence. We worked on it in our spare time, over about months, and we had to start bright and early to avoid the blistering summer heat. (Hipwaders are hot at the best of times.) But at least we had the mosquitos to keep us company! - Kerry
caption_cleaned: four biologists two front one way back truly behind camera installing fence small tree lined wetland Last Mountain Lake National Wildlife Area NWA Saskatchewan need fences like one keep local vegetation wandering NWA onto roads neighbouring properties munch away keep grasslands healthy took lot elbow grease install km fence worked spare time months start bright early avoid blistering summer heat Hipwaders hot best times least mosquitos keep us company Kerry

caption_original: This winter, we are going to live vicariously through these whimbrels as they set their sights on warmer wintering grounds.Working with partners, we’ve equipped these migratory birds with transmitters to track their journey from Miscou Island in New Brunswick, Canada, to Brazil. Knowing where they are going and how fast they are travelling can give biologists a better idea of what sort of threats they might be facing during their travels.
caption_cleaned: winter going live vicariously whimbrels set sights warmer wintering grounds nWorking partners equipped migratory birds transmitters track journey Miscou Island New Brunswick Canada Brazil Knowing going fast travelling give biologists better idea sort threats might facing travels mountallison usfws

caption_original: Good news comes on Friday! The Randle Reef Sediment Remediation Project is cleaning up Hamilton Harbour. Yay clean water! The engineered containment facility (or ECF) pictured here acts like a box that will store the yuckiest of sediment. When the $138.9 million project is complete in , it will make the water cleaner for the fish & us to enjoy, and bring jobs and tourism to the local community. Hooray!!!!! : Bermingham Foundation Solutions

caption_original: “It’s getting hot in here” or is it just this carefully planned grassland fire? Biologist and Fireboss Kerry stands to watch as her colleague Sarah steps back from the flames while lighting up the primary fireline – Woah!!! A controlled burn can help keep ecosystems healthy by reducing the number of shrubs and trees, & removing old plant material that builds up over years.

caption_original: Oh BUOY! What a boat! Come on board! The Canadian Coast Guard Ship (CCGS) Limnos calls Burlington, Ontario, its home, where it is docked at the Canada Centre for Inland Water (more often than knot). Puns are totally intended. Taking its name from “limnology,” the study of inland waters, CCGS Limnos is the dedicated scientific vessel for our environmental research and monitoring on the Great Lakes. It is capable of sampling the water, using a wide array of equipment, and it is equipped with an on-board laboratory for the processing and analysis of samples. How neat is that?

caption_original: Meet Sue, a water scientist who studies harmful algal blooms, at our lab in Burlington. Sue will be retiring in December, and we wish her all the best!
